title: Choi Duk-hoon
text:
Choi Duk-hoon (also "Choi Deok-hun", ; born March 5, 1976 in <a href="Seoul">Seoul</a>) is a retired amateur South Korean Greco-Roman wrestler, who competed in the men's middleweight category. He produced a remarkable tally of three career medals, including a gold in the 74-kg division at the <a href="2003%20Asian%20Wrestling%20Championships">2003 Asian Wrestling Championships</a> in <a href="Delhi%2C%20India">Delhi, India</a>, and also finished tenth at the <a href="2004%20Summer%20Olympics">2004 Summer Olympics</a>, representing his nation <a href="South%20Korea">South Korea</a>. Having worked as a full-time employee for <a href="Sung%20Shin">Sung Shin</a>, Choi trained throughout his sporting career as a member of its wrestling team under head coach Bang Dae-du.
Choi highlighted his sporting career at the <a href="2003%20Asian%20Wrestling%20Championships">2003 Asian Wrestling Championships</a> in <a href="Delhi%2C%20India">Delhi, India</a>, where he captured a gold medal over India's Sanjay Kumar in the 74-kg division with a comfortable 7–0 decision.
At the <a href="2004%20Summer%20Olympics">2004 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="Athens">Athens</a>, Choi qualified for the South Korean squad, as a 28-year-old, in the <a href="Wrestling%20at%20the%202004%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20Greco-Roman%2074%20kg">men's 74 kg</a> class. Earlier in the process, he placed third in the same class at the Asian Championships in <a href="Almaty%2C%20Kazakhstan">Almaty, Kazakhstan</a> to guarantee a spot on South Korea's Olympic wrestling team. He lost his opening match 2–6 to two-time reigning Olympic champion <a href="Filiberto%20Azcuy">Filiberto Azcuy</a> of Cuba, but bounced back to oust Poland's <a href="Rados%C5%82aw%20Truszkowski">Radosław Truszkowski</a> with a challenging 6–1 verdict. Placing second in the prelim pool and tenth overall, Choi failed to advance to the quarterfinals.
